title: Aircraft viewing area near Melbourne Airport to become tourist attraction
text:
Aircraft viewing area near Melbourne Airport to become tourist attraction Adv: 
Jul 19, 2015 Adv: 
MELBOURNE, Australia - An ambitious plan to turn an aircraft viewing area into a thriving tourist hub with produce stalls could inject millions of dollars into Hume’s economy. 
Hume councilor Casey Nunn has called for the VicRoads-owned site in Bulla to be spruced up and in turn boost tourist numbers. 
It comes on the back of a Hume Leader report last month about a series of dangerous potholes that opened up at the Oaklands Rd site, which have since been patched up. 
“I just feel it’s a very popular site, especially with locals (as well as) those who don’t live in the area,” Cr Nunn said. 
“I often take my nephews there to have an ice-cream and watch the planes.” 
Cr Nunn said an overhaul could capitalize on passengers arriving at Melbourne airport. 
“(About) 30 million people land at Melbourne airport every year. 
“If we could get 1 per cent of (those) people to attend, that’s a lot.” 
Cr Nunn said it could include an airplane-themed playground, food and beverage stalls with local produce, and an interactive zone. 
The site would also be good for transit passengers who wanted to see Australian wildlife at the neighboring Woodlands Historic Park and horses at Living Legends. 
“We have fantastic food and beverages in the city, so (we could be) showcasing some of those features. 
“It would be a great way to stimulate the economy.” 
Daylesford Macedon Ranges Tourism Board general manager Judith Isherwood praised the idea. 
“I know for a fact that there are many, many people who find (plane watching) endlessly fascinating,” she said. 
“Any ideas that bring a sense of place and a sense of location into the airport, particularly for transit passengers who may only have that as a brief experience, can only be a good thing.” 
In 2012, Jacksons Creek ward councilor Jack Ogilvie proposed a transmitter tower be built so plane-spotters could hear air traffic controllers giving pilots instructions. 
VicRoads metro north west regional director Vince Punaro said he was exploring long-term improvements to the car park and would work with the council and Melbourne airport on any proposals to enhance visitors’ experience.
